Package jdk.test.lib.hotspot.ir_framework

Annotation Interface Check

@Retention(RUNTIME) public @interface Check
Annotation for a check method of a checked test.

Let t be a test method specifying the @Test annotation and c be a check method specifying the @Check(test = "t") annotation. These two methods represent a so-called checked test. The only difference to a base test (see Test) is that the framework will invoke the check method c directly after the invocation of the test method t which allows to do some additional verification, including the return value of t. The framework does the following, similar as for base tests:

  1. The framework warms t up by invoking it for a predefined number of iterations (default: 2000) or any number specified by an additional @Warmup annotation at t or by using TestFramework.setDefaultWarmup(int) (could also be 0 which skips the warm-up completely which is similar to simulating -Xcomp). After each invocation of t, the framework also invokes c if the @Check annotation specifies CheckAt.EACH_INVOCATION at when(). More information about the warm-up in general can be found at Warmup

  2. After the warm-up, the framework compiles t at the specified compilation level set by Test.compLevel() (default CompLevel.ANY will pick the highest available level which is usually CompLevel.C2).

  3. The framework invokes t one more time to run the compilation. Afterwards, the framework will always invoke c again to be able perform additional checks after the compilation of t.

  4. The framework checks any specified @IR constraints at the test method t. More information about IR matching can be found at IR.

The test method t has the same properties and follows the same constraints as stated in Test.

The following additional constraints must be met for the test method t and check method c:

  • c must specify the method name t as property in @Check(test = "t") (see test(). Specifying a non-@Test annotated method or a @Test method that has already been used by another @Check or @Run method results in a TestFormatException.

  • c can specify the following method parameter combinations:

    • void

    • One parameter: TestInfo which provides some information about t and utility methods.

    • One parameter: the exact same type as the return value of t. When c is invoked by the framework, this parameter contains the return value of t.

    • 1st parameter: TestInfo; 2nd parameter: the exact same type as the return value of t (see above)

    • Any other combination will result in a TestFormatException.

  • c is not compiled nor inlined.

  • c must be part of the test class. Using @Check in nested or other classes is not allowed.

  • c cannot specify any helper-method-specific compile command annotations (@ForceCompile, @DontCompile, @ForceInline, @DontInline).

If no verification is required, use a base test (see Test). If t must be invoked with more complex or varying arguments and/or the t must be invoked differently in subsequent invocations, use a custom run test (see Run).

Examples on how to write checked tests can be found in CheckedTestExample and also as part of the internal testing in the package jdk.test.lib.hotspot.ir_framework.tests.

See Also:
Test, TestInfo, CheckAt

  • Required Element Summary

    Required Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Required Element
    Description
    String
    test
    The unique associated Test method for this @Check annotated check method.

  • Optional Element Summary

    Optional Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Optional Element
    Description
    CheckAt
    when
    When should the @Check method be invoked? By default, the check is done after each invocation which is encouraged if performance is not critical.

  • Element Details

    • test

      String test
      The unique associated Test method for this @Check annotated check method. The framework will directly invoke the @Check method after each invocation or only after the compilation of the associated @Test method (depending on the value set with when()).

      If a non-@Test annotated method or a @Test method that has already been used by another @Check or Run method is specified, then a TestFormatException is thrown.

      See Also:
      Test

    • when

      CheckAt when
      When should the @Check method be invoked? By default, the check is done after each invocation which is encouraged if performance is not critical.
      See Also:
      CheckAt
      Default:
      EACH_INVOCATION
